Use the IDE to create a new project
Start the IDE
This will be something like:
http://apps.dynamide.com:8080/dynamide/ide
depending on how you have Resin configured for hostname and port.
Cancel out of the dialog that asks you to choose a project.
Click "New Project".
Fill in the form that comes up
If you want to create a new application, say it is called "/Dynamie/myapp", and your login is "joe", and you have decided to put your applications under a site called "mysite", you would enter the following data:
URL Path for New Project: [ /dynamide/myapp ]
Site Name: [ mysite ]
Application name relative to apps/: [ myapp ]
Use User Sandbox: [ ]
User Directory: [ joe ]
This could be accessed from a URL such as http://apps.dynamide.com:8080/myapp
You could have a URI of "/foo/myapp" and still have an application name of "myapp", in which case you'd enter:
URL Path for New Project: [ /dynamide/myapp ]
Site Name: [ mysite ]
Application name relative to apps/: [ myapp ]
Use User Sandbox: [ ]
User Directory: [ joe ]
These two methods would look the same on disk, but simple have a different URL mapping.
Note: for the current release of Dynamide, you must preface all URI's with /dynamide.
After you see the success dialog, click OK.
The IDE should open the new project for you.
If not, click Open Project, and type in the URL you selected above (e.g. "/myapp").
The IDE should create a default page (of type com.dynamide.form) "page1" for you. If not, select the page type from the dropdown labelled "Pagetypes:", then click New Page.
You can save changes to your pages with Save Page, which applies to the page selected in the Windows dropdown list -- this is currently different than Open Page behavior.
Save the project with Save Project.
You can close the IDE by closing the top IDE window.
You can now run your project in the development web server, and you will get a blank page served up.
Use the IDE to modify your first Page.
Start with Use the IDE to create a new project or use Open Project >> Open Page.
Open Page always acts on the page selected in the Page List dropdown.
With the Page:
Enter new text. Should only be allowed outside of widgets.
Click in existing widgets (with red dotted border).
property inspector should pop up. You can set properties and tab out or hit the Enter key to apply the property value.
Add new widgets.
Click on widget type (e.g. "com.dynamide.edit")
Click on checkbox: "Drop Components"
Click on page somewhere -- widget appears.
Un-check "Drop Components" when done.
Click on new widget. Property page appears.
Set a property and see the effect.
"Caption" usually is apparent.
Don't change "name" property.
Save the page with "Save Page".
You can also edit the HTML source of the page. Click Save Page. Click "Edit Page Source", edit the HTML, click Save, then close the resulting message page.
Go back to the IDE, close the WYSIWYG window, and re-open the page.
Use the IDE to create an Application Widget (using containers)
In addition to the widgets that ship with Dynamide, you can create your own widgets. Widgets encapsulate some functionality and some layout, or presentation. You can author Widgets by hand, and add them to the widget library. But you can also have application-specific widgets. These you create in GUI mode using the Dynamide IDE. You create a page that has other widgets on it, and events and behavior you want. You save the page within the current application, then, from another page, you include the application-specific widget by using a com.dynamide.container.
In this step, we are going to create a page, save that page, then include it on another page as a widget.
Select the page type from the dropdown labelled "Pagetypes:". For this example, use "com.dynamide.page".
Click "New Page", and enter a unique name for the page (should be a valid javascript identifier), for example, "widgetPage1".
Drop components on the page, and enter text.
Add page events.
Save the page with "Save Page". Make sure both the "Page List" and "Windows" dropdowns have your new page selected.
Save the project.
Open another page, or create one of pagetype "com.dynamide.form".
On this other page, drop a com.dynamide.container.
Click inside the container -- this sets the property editor to point to this new container, which will be named something like "com_dynamide_container1".
Set the pageName property to the widget page you just created and saved. For example, "widgetPage1".
Save the page you are working on.
If anything gets out of sync, save the page, save the project, and click "Open Page". This reloads your page.
